metadata.sermon_title: Seeing Sin as God Sees It—Psalm 51
metadata.sermon_start_end: I HEARD on the radio this morning that Fred Goldman has made O. J. Simpson an offer. He will withdraw any and all financial claims if O. J. will sign a detailed written confession. [...] As St. Paul writes in the Ash Wednesday Epistle, “God made him [Jesus] to be sin who knew no sin, that in him we might become the righteousness of God.” AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses on Psalm 51, but it treats the text more as a general 'masterpiece of self-knowledge' rather than mining it for what is unique to this specific passage. It identifies the theological nature of sin in verse 4 as a key point, which is adequate, but it leans heavily on the general theme of confession found elsewhere.
quotes: Psalm 51, the Ash Wednesday Psalm, is the acknowledged masterpiece of biblical self-knowledge.
The reason for this is of central importance. Sin, at bottom, is not an ethical concept at all. It is a theological concept.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify what Psalm 51 says about the 're-creation' of the heart (v. 10) that distinguishes it from other penitential psalms or general calls to repentance.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is thin. While the Davidic tradition is mentioned, there is no engagement with the Hebrew text or the specific cultic/theological history of Israel. The preacher relies more on modern literary critics (Janet Malcolm) and cultural references (O.J. Simpson) than on the original context of the pericope.
quotes: Traditionally it has been attributed to King David at the time of his adultery with Bathsheba.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the linguistic weight of terms like 'blot out' (māḥâ) or 'wash' (kābas) to show the specific Israelite understanding of ritual and moral purity.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete and contemporary, utilizing the zeitgeist of the late 90s (O.J. Simpson, Truth and Reconciliation Commission). It successfully moves from general 'apology' to the specific theological necessity of confession before God.
quotes: He will withdraw any and all financial claims if O. J. will sign a detailed written confession.
In South Africa, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission has been charged with eliciting confessions...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond the 'psychology of confession' to the concrete 'misery' of the congregation's specific current context.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a pattern of 'illustration-text-illustration'. While not a strict 15/5 split, the text often serves as a springboard for cultural commentary rather than the hearer being 'expounded' through the text itself.
quotes: The writer Janet Malcolm has written about people who are unable to confess...
I believe it was the Duke of Wellington who was supposed to have said...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Allow the biblical text to drive the narrative flow rather than using external anecdotes to frame the biblical verses.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The three parts are present. Misery is defined as the lack of self-knowledge and sin against God. Redemption is found in the 'Another' (Christ). Gratitude is implied in the 'joy and gladness' of the new creation, though less developed.
quotes: On Ash Wednesday, we come together to acknowledge that God has a case against us...
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'gratitude' section by showing how the 'clean heart' results in a specific life of service, not just a feeling of relief.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are largely absent. While 'being lost' is mentioned in the context of self-deception, the ultimate seriousness of the narrow vs. broad way is softened by a focus on psychological maturity and 'handsome apologies'.
quotes: It takes maturity, wisdom, and true manliness to offer a handsome apology.
These are the people who never feel in the wrong... and who in the end … cause their fallible fellow-men to turn away from them.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'judgment' mentioned in verse 4 with more gravity, pointing to the reality of being lost in time or eternity if the 'case' God has against us is not resolved.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The preacher avoids the pitfall of 'moralizing' the Psalm by pointing to the substitutionary work of Christ as the only solution to the 'storm'.
quotes: There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself and, in so doing, has nullified it.
Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place, naked in the storm.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure the transition to Christ feels necessitated by the specific 'misery' of Psalm 51 rather than being a standard dogmatic addition at the end.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 14.5 minutes, the sermon fails Dekker's 20-minute threshold. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true homiletical depth, relying on quick-fire illustrations rather than sustained theological exposition.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to provide the necessary 'breadth' for the 'depth' of the subject matter.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its insufficient length and lack of rigorous exegesis. It relies heavily on psychological insights and cultural anecdotes (O.J. Simpson, Mozart) which, while concrete, occasionally overshadow the specific biblical text. However, it successfully identifies Christ as the telos and maintains a clear distinction between ethical and theological concepts of sin.
strengths: Strong Christocentric conclusion that avoids moralism.
Concrete contemporary application that engages the zeitgeist.
Clear articulation of sin as a theological rather than merely ethical category.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (under 15 minutes) prevents theological depth.
Lack of engagement with original biblical languages and historical context.
The 'two ways' and the seriousness of being lost are underdeveloped.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate speech with strong theological instincts, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the full Dekkerian sense. It lacks the exegetical rigor and the 'breadth' of time necessary to truly recreate the Word of God for the current moment.
